that she has a special kind of responsibility for it, a responsibility that gives
it rights against her which are not possessed by an independent person—
such as an ailing violinist who is a stranger to her.
On the other hand, this argument would give the unborn person a right
to its mother’s body only if her pregnancy resulted from a voluntary act, un-
dertaken in full knowledge of the chance a pregnancy might result from it.
